query: What is the success rate of reintroducing captive-bred bats into areas affected by white-nose syndrome?
relevant_summary: No studies have evaluated the effects of breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome, so no success rates of reintroduction are reported [2009].

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"success rate of reintroducing captive-bred bats into areas affected by white-nose syndrome", "k": 3, "offset": 0}
{"query_string":"success rate of reintroducing captive-bred bats into areas affected by white-nose syndrome", "k": 3, "offset": 3}
{"action_id":"2053"}
tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "2053",
  "action_title": "Breed bats in captivity",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eight studies evaluated the effects of breeding bats in captivity on bat populations. Three studies were in the USA, two in the UK, and one in each of Italy, Brazil and New Zealand.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (8 STUDIES)

Reproductive success (6 studies): Six studies in the USA, UK, Italy and Brazil found that 6–100% of female bats captured in the wild successfully conceived, gave birth and reared young in captivity. Two studies in the UK and Brazil found that two of five and two of three bats born in captivity successfully gave birth to live young.
Survival (8 studies): Seven studies in the USA, UK, Italy and Brazil found that 20–100% of bat pups born in captivity survived from between 10 days to adulthood. One study in New Zealand found that two of five New Zealand lesser short-tailed bat pups born in captivity survived, both of which were hand-reared.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

tools_called.args: {"action_id":"2009"}

query: Will training arborists to identify potential bat roosts (Action 1981) be more effective than protecting known roost trees during forest operations (Action 1982)?
relevant_summary: The available action documents report no studies evaluating the effects of training arborists and forestry operatives to identify potential bat roosts on bat populations (Action 1981) [1981], and no studies evaluating the effects of protecting roost trees during forest operations on bat populations (Action 1982) [1982]. Therefore, effectiveness and potential harmful impacts for both actions have not been assessed based on current evidence in these documents [1981, 1982].

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "bat roosts arborist training known roost trees forest operations", "k": 3, "offset": 0}
{"query_string":"bat roosts arborist training known roost trees forest operations","k":3,"offset":3}

{"action_id":"1982"}
